title: John Cooper Clarke webchat - as it happened | Stage | The Guardian
summary: and here 's a priceless photo of john at the guardian .
post your questions for john cooper clarke .

documents.title: we 're wrapping up
text: well this was intense !

thanks to everyone who posted questions , and very especially to john for answering so many of them , so brilliantly and so quickly - he almost certainly has become the record holder for the higher number of questions answered on a webchat .
ever .
thanks everyone !
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 5:07pm keep watching the schedules , i 'll be coming to a town near you in the not too distant future .
and if you live in london , i 'll be seeing some of you at the royal festival hall on the south bank this coming saturday .
until then , mazel tov .
ulsterfry asked : what do you think of limericks ?
do you write any yourself or know any good ones ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 5:06pm i love limericks .
i like any set piece like that : haikus , but limericks especially .
people feel cheated if there is n't a disgusting pay off line .
i ca n't think of a clean limerick i tried to write some for the lucrative christmas stocking market .
i knew a fella called kenclimbing up the hands of big benascending at noonhe fell to his doomat precisely six-thirty pm .
then they get a bit more off colour , like this : i knew a fella called frankhis wife was a bit of a skankhe wrote down her pinbefore doing her inand laughed all the way to the bank .
and there 's : a stay at home lady named rozsaid i do n't go out much becausei already knowwherever i goi 'd wish i 'd just stayed where i was .
here 's another one .
two ugly sisters from fordhamtook a walk one day out of boredomon the way backa sex maniacjumped out of a bush and ignored 'em .
ciaranliam asks : samuel taylor coleridge or mark edward smith ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 5:00pm i ca n't see any difference .

steamedgreens asks : now that journalism and other forms of fiction have had their collective ass whipped by the new electronic media , do you ever jump for joy that now journalists , novelists , and other dime-store hacks know the pain of abject poverty and voicelessness like you poets do ?
huh ?
do ya ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 5:00pm no , i 'm an avid reader of newspapers and columnists .
they 're kind of an addiction for me .
i do n't think they 've been displaced .
more means worse , in most cases .
to get a job on one of the major national dailies , you 've have to proven yourself to have something .
i do n't mean that in an old school tie sort of way , but opinions are like arseholes - everybody 's got one .
i 'm a democrat , people should have their voice , but i think there 's always going to be a meritocracy in every area and why should writing be exempt from that ?
like rolling news - where 's the perspective ?
it 's all do n't watch that , watch this , never mind about that , watch this .
you 've got three stories at any one time , and does anyone know any more than they did before ?
what i like to do is read the news of a month old newspaper , look at what they were trying to get worried about a month ago .
i would n't deny anybody a voice , but i 'm more interested in say rod liddle has got to say , for instance , than some herbert on the internet .
seoulderry asks : why do you not favour the sock as part of the suit 's ensemble ?
i only heard a snippet of the bbc 6 show on sunday .
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:56pm good question .
i 've always seen them as kind of underwear .
they 're foundation garments , something that comes in between a boot and the skin .
i do n't want to be too hard and fast about this , i know people who really work the sock and good luck to them , but me i 've always been a boot wearer .
i do wear them but you ca n't see them .
you do n't need hosiery on a man , there 's something effeminate about it .
they 're necessary , know what i mean ?
samsears3 asks : was nico fun to hang out with ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:54pm fun is a big word but she was lovely .
peterkimpton asks : best or charlton ?
or is there another greatest ever red ?
and what 's your favourite word ?
try not to say best or charlton .
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:53pm george best .
and duncan edwards .
best , he was always pulling something out of the hat , good with both feet , and more than just a one trick pony .
a creative player .
very glamourous , in a world that did n't have much glamour attached to it at the time - outside of italy .
starspeakman asks : what advice would you give a middle aged poet struggling to get published ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:51pm the only way i know is to do gigs .
do gigs , and you do n't even need a publisher - knock up a book and sell them at shows .
the best way to discover anyone 's poetry is to read it aloud .
if it does n't sound good , it is n't any good .
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:52pm but it 's never been easy .
and it 's never been easier .
if you 've got a laptop you can knock up a sample of your work , do live performances and sell them at the door .
retiredarch asks : hey john - keep on , keeping on , do it just right .
why elvis films ?
you were the only reason i bothered watching something i usually avoid .
said hello to you at a gig in the mid/late seventies .
my manc girlfriend at the time was besotted with you , and claimed that she wanted to have your children .
children john ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:50pm on celebrity mastermind ?
well , at the time i thought i knew everything about elvis movies but then i realised he 'd made 34 movies .
i had thought it would be a walk in the park .
but the revision was a pleasure .
some are better than others , but he never made a bad movie .
deanw asks : john - teenage werewolf is incredibly funky !
at one point in my mispent yoot it was a five times a day play .
would you consider making more like this and shocking everyone ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:49pm that 's always the plan when i write a poem , it 's always going to be the best thing i 've ever done or what 's the point ?
calciozucchini asks : dear mr clarke i have been wearing sunglasses for most of my 23 years in existence , i do not wish to remove them - the power is in the wearing .
i wear black carrera 6000s - simple black frames / lens gradient .
carrera because they reminded me of my first love = skiing .
however , lately i have had the tremors of social pressure pounding down no me to remove them .
if i was to compromise and take them off now and again , when would be the best moment to do this ?
are there any opportune times to remove sunglasses without compromising my art ( and vision ) guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:48pm what are you trying to do here ?
are you perfecting a man of mystery type identity ?
in which case , you ca n't take them off .
good times to remove sunglasses ?
bedtime .
in the shower - they steam up .
hubbahubba says : have you ever experienced writers bock , and if so , what , if anything , inspires you out of it ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:47pm oh yeah .
for a decade .
but i ca n't remember how i got out of it - suddenly i could do it again .
but art , it 's a cruel mistress .
she could walk out at any time .
i know because it 's happened .
so i write home all the time .

id0511953 asks : hi john your poems change over time i remember the line margaret thatcher is stunning , yes , but i 've never seen a nipple in the daily express '' that got replaced in later versions .
did it change because the kids today ca n't remember thatcher ?
have you ever changed a poem and upset people ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:45pm i do n't do that poem any more , on account of the daily express being taken over by a porn baron , mr desmond .
you could n't make it up .
so it no longer applies , is what i 'm saying .
traveller3 asks : what would you rhyme with guardian ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:44pm not easy , these questions .
beyonce , guardian i 'm going to stick my neck out and say nothing rhymes with guardian .
cardigan ?
bit laboured , that .
no way , and i 'm a professional .
id6316065 asks : hi john .
do you have any burning ambitions you 've yet to fulfill ?
places to be ?
people to meet ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:43pm i once said i fancied a knighthood , but i 'm quite happy being a doctor , that 'll do me .
as a medical guy .
soapbox22 asks : do you read traditional poetry , and do you think that reading poetry is an important part of creative education for kids ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:41pm yeah , i have done .
my taste in poetry is really quite old school .
i favour rhyme - i tend to go a traditional route .
kipling was a big figure in my poetry education back in school .
sir henry newbolt , people like that .

skepticsayer asks : i recently interviewed burmese punk vocalist skum about art in burma pre and post military junta , he was very disappointed that burma had n't found its own voice artistically and that he and others were mainly looking to the west for inspiration still .
what are your thoughts about artistic voice and regional or national identity ; does it matter ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:40pm as a poet , i feel very lucky to be english .
i think it 's everyone 's favourite language : it 's official .
check the figures .
there 's no better language to be a writer in .
bubobubo asks : what 's your favourite owl ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:39pm i like 'em all .
they 're all great .
ken cunningham asks : john , i 've heard you like martinis .
how do you like yours and which gin ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:39pm gin is the alcohol equivalent of ham - i 've never had any i did n't like .
cheap , expensive , there 's no such thing as unpalatable gin .
i 've never had a slice of ham i did n't enjoy , you just ca n't go wrong .
pesheva75 asks : is it a barmcake or a muffin ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:37pm i 'm sufficiently northern to say barmcake .
aggressivepassive asks : hi john , what 's your favourite rhyme from a song ?
i kind of like stephen stills ' from johnny 's garden and it 's green and it 's quiet only trouble was i had to buy it even though i do n't know why .
cheers guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:36pm from in a mountain greenery , but mel torme : it 's an internal rhyme .
beans could get no keener re- ception - in a beanery.god bless our mountain greenery , far from lives ' machinerygod bless our mountain greenery home .
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:36pm that 's mel `` the velvet fog '' torme .
themaskedmarvel asks : who is your personal trainer ?
is it peter perret ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:33pm no , he 's far too energetic for me .
knulp40 asks : did you have anyone specific in mind when you wrote twat ?
i think we should know .
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:33pm not really .
it comes up for review every so often .
holgerczukay asks : as a lover of a good shoe , do you have a favourite ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:32pm that 's a good question .
i 'm a great fan of the firm jeffrey-west .
available from sir tom baker 's tailor shop in d'arblay street .
my favourite pair are burgundy suede chelsea boots , with a slightly raised heel .
ejmd asks : how long before it all goes horribly wrong ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:30pm give it a fortnight , tops .
id6440291 asks : i read i wan na be yours to my wife at her wedding and we both cried like mad .
do any other of your poems cause such emotional outpourings ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:30pm that bad eh ?
actually , you 've hit on one there .
i wan na be yours , even before the monkeys put it on their album , it became a wedding favourite .
in this secular age people are bringing people up to date .
i wan na be yours is to 21st century weddings what eric idle 's always look on the bright side of life is to humanist funerals .
razclaut asks : dear john , do you have any words which may help us understand where we are today as a society ?
best , raz .
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:29pm smarter men than me - i have n't got a clue .
thedailybumbler asks : do you follow stand-up comedy ?
if so , who are your favourite stand-ups ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:28pm the first standup comedian i ever saw was in 1958 , and i never saw anyone better than that : bob hope .
i do n't know what it was , i was the only nine year old in there and all his jokes were about golf , divorce , domestic situations but it was the way he told them .
there was only one guy in the theatre that was n't laughing and that was bob hope .
he takes some following .
but there are loads of great comedians around today - particularly sean lock , he nearly killed me .
it 's not easy to laugh on your own , i was in a hotel room on my own watching him on tv , and i nearly died laughing .
i actually choked .
unbelievably funny guy .
big big fan .
i like jackie mason too , love him .
i liked american comedians , i was a big dean martin fan so i got into joey bishop , don rickles , those 50s comedians .
thejunkyardangel asks : what is your favourite dylan song and album ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:24pm highway 61 revisited .
song , that 's impossible brand new leopard skin pillbox hat , whatever that song is .
bennoo says : john , have you ever considered doing the shipping forecast on bbc r4 lw ?
i think you would sound fantastic .
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:23pm i have n't considered it , no , but why not ?
killickthere asks : what impact has evidently chickentown had on your life ?
are the lines , the fucking food is fucking muck the fucking drains are fucking fucked the best you have ever written ?
they are certainly my favourites .
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:22pm you 're a person of great discernment and i could n't agree more .
that 's probably got me further than any poem i 've ever written - it got me in the joy division film control , on the credits of the sopranos .
i 've no idea how the sopranos thing came about - they made me an offer i could n't understand .
it 's a top number that , i love it .
robbo100 asks : what does john think of the late great bill hicks ' claim that anyone who sells their name to advertisers loses all artistic credibility ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:21pm could n't agree more .
everybody likes chips , but nobody wants their house to smell like a chip shop , so it 's a great invention .
and of course as internetdemocrats says , there 's a health and safety aspect to this .
arover56 asks : do n't you get fucked off with being called the punk poet ? ''
remember wally the hook armed landlord in the star in lower broughton ?
whatever happened to jim staley ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:20pm the word that rescues that is `` the '' .
as long as it 's `` the punk poet '' and not `` a punk poet '' , i do n't have a problem with it .
surulere says : love your voice and your writing .
my question , or challenge is unless you 've already done so , can you write a poem with words that rhyme with beyonce ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:19pm i can only think of fiancee .
or poncey .
that 's it is n't it ?
if anyone can enlighten me on this list of words if you 'd said adele i could have come up with a million .
tweedie asks : do you actually delight in eating chips for tea `` and are mccain 's aware of the possibility of irony in the message conveyed in the ad ( depending on how it 's read , i.e .
the same words could be read in a sneering tone , changing the meaning entirely ) .
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:18pm i love chips .
i pity the fool who does n't .
you 'll never get food poisoning in a chip shop - what could live in those temperatures ?
franks asks : do you prefer the pink or white coloured turkish delight ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:17pm the pink .
it 's made with rosewater , with that nice floral flavour .
and it 's full of eastern promise obviously .
terryfookwitt asks : how do you keep your svelte figure ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:16pm eating plenty of peas .
misereremei asks : do you prefer peas or beans ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:15pm peas .
[ thinks ] good question really i do n't know .
fran maccarthy says : thomas dequincey 's confessions of an english opium eater or baudelaire 's les fleurs du mal .
please one , or better yet , indulge us with your thoughts on both .
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:14pm les fleurs du mal .
i was always interested in baudelaire , ever since i found out he was a careful dresser .
i 'm always interested in people 's sartorial choices .
he was the first modern guy , really .
surulere asks : which street in brixton did you used to live ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:13pm effra road .
nice place .
gaybasil asks about the arctic monkeys : do you have a view on arctic monkeys progression ?
a favourite album of theirs ?
( might be biased toward am i suppose ) .
aside from alex , are there enough people keeping that love of english , and language and poetry , alive in music entertainment ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:12pm so far they have n't put a foot wrong .
my favourite album of theirs as you 've already said is am , for the simple reason that it contains some of my lyrics .

documents.title: and here 's a priceless photo of john at the guardian
text: john cooper clarke in the guardian offices before dipping into your questions .
beaumont-thomas
schwarzschwan asks : johnny clarke , not only britain 's greatest living poet , but a man who knows his chips .
mmm home chips - crinkle cut .
i am very interested in your eschewment of the internet and would like to hear your viewpoint on it .
what changes has this technology imposed on our society/culture and where do you see it all going in the future ?

guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:12pm my eschewment of the internet is n't out of any luddite sort of hatred of technology - i just know how great it is , and if i had a computer , you 'd find me in six weeks time dead under a pile of pizza boxes .
so i ca n't go there .
stephanobentos asks : who would play at a dr jcc curated music festival ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:10pm dion .
veronica spector .
smokey robinson .
brenda lee .
the fall .
the stones .
bobbysixty asks : john , i first saw you perform live in 1979 : you do n't appear to have aged a day since .
what 's your secret ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:09pm no secret .
but i do n't really agree , given i have instant access to my face on a daily basis .
but i 'm glad this person thinks so .
i will take that in the spirit that it 's offered , as a compliment .
ferrytuckwitt asks : beasley street is a place that is found in most towns and cities in the uk , but were there any streets/areas in particular which inspired this song ?

guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:08pm very little of my stuff is written from personal experience , but beasely street was inspired by a particular thoroughfare in manchester , camp street .

the thing about beasely street is that i wrote the last line first , it was inspired by a big musical number called 42nd street , from the movie 42nd street , a busy berkeley movie - one of those with highly choreographed films with hundreds of dancers .
it 's the big production number , set in new york - it ends with the line naughty , gaudy , sporty , shorty or something 42nd street .
i thought that 's a good way of finishing a song about a street .
what would rhyme with greasy ?
beasley street .
but the actual street was camp street .
but i could n't call it that , as it might come across as having some gay baggage - camp , it 's a highly charged word .
it was a low rent sort of area , a ghetto .
victorian houses inadequately converted into cheap flats .
it 's tweaked though , it 's not hyper realistic .
a lot of my favourite songs are about areas and streets : the sunny side of the street , dead end street by ray davies , desolation row .
always a good subject for poetry .

documents.title: john is in the house
text: here we go !
john has just arrived to guardian towers and is ready to answer as many questions as he can in the next hour .
he has started with madmonk35 's query about how he 's finding the south-east essex seems an odd choice of abode for you , do you miss the banter and friendliness of the north-west ?
guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:02pm there 's plenty of banter and friendliness in the south-east .
i 've lived there longer than i 've lived anywhere else : 25 years , so there 's something about it i like .
it 's 50 minutes out of london , 45 from clacton-on-sea - something for everyone really .

nice neighbours , they keep themselves to themselves guardian contributor johncclarke 30 september 2014 4:03pm top of me head : you ca n't get meat and potatoes in fish and chip shops in the south east .
a minor quibble .
all things considered though , essex is god 's country .

documents.title: post your questions for john cooper clarke
text: with his dark sunglasses , shock of black hair and gold teeth , 'punk poet ' john cooper clarke is instantly recognisable - but it 's his voice that hits you first .
a drily amused salford drawl , he applies it in rhythmic streams of poetic consciousness .
his to poverty , love , and all the petty little things that both irritate and make life worth living .
i wan na be your setting lotion / hold your hair in deep devotion . ''

he started out in cabaret before ending up in punk clubs , delivering bile in between bands - it had , by his own admission , a massive impact on british culture everybody that read one of my poems went off and wrote poetry . ''
the 80s saw him release albums , do madcap sugar puffs adverts , and become addicted to heroin , the latter inducing a long spell of no writing at all .
but he got clean , and found a new generation of converts .
the arctic monkeys reworked his poem i wan na be yours , while plan b put clarke in his film ill manors , and his tones could even be heard singing the praises of mccain chips .
his fortunes have risen far enough to mean he 's now headlining a night at the royal festival hall on 4 october .
to mark the occasion , he 's joining us to answer your questions .
post them in the comments below , and he 'll endeavour to answer as many as possible from 4-5pm on tuesday september 30 .

Post your questions for John Cooper Clarke

bulletin.text: The Mancunian punk poet beloved of Alex Turner and Plan B was with us and answered many of your questions - from his favourite word to his favourite owl, via his admission of a decade-long writers' block, here are all his brilliant answers.
